text: Am I the only one who doesn't care about roi? Obviously it depends how you operate but for my part I don't think it matters - just profit per transaction. Surely roi only matters if you've got limited funds and you need to best deploy them, for many scenarios you can easily have more available then the market will support and all that really matters is the stake/value trade off - or am I missing something?

text: I look at a whole bunch of things separately: Profit on each transaction if fully matched at flat stakes, proportion of that realised and so on. Optimising stakes for similar transactions is just profit. I also run a fixed 'benchmark' simulation on every market so that I can compare groups of markets in terms of their overall capacity for getting value bets in and try to control for the background performance of markets in that way (to factor out things like the post lockdown surge). It get quite complex though.

elements.text: I look at a whole bunch of things separately: Profit on each transaction if fully matched at flat stakes, proportion of that realised and so on. Optimising stakes for similar transactions is just profit. I also run a fixed 'benchmark' simulation on every market so that I can compare groups of markets in terms of their overall capacity for getting value bets in and try to control for the background performance of markets in that way (to factor out things like the post lockdown surge). It get quite complex though.

text: I have found a couple of inplay strategies via Flumine backtesting that are showing a positive return over 500 markets/~4000 bets. Going to test against a bigger sample, but am just wondering how backtesting compares to live betting? I've not (yet) run any live betting with Flumine as I'm taking cautious steps due to the sheer speed of streaming, which means a small mistake can quickly become expensive. What would you consider as a "goer"?

elements.text: I have found a couple of inplay strategies via Flumine backtesting that are showing a positive return over 500 markets/~4000 bets. Going to test against a bigger sample, but am just wondering how backtesting compares to live betting? I've not (yet) run any live betting with Flumine as I'm taking cautious steps due to the sheer speed of streaming, which means a small mistake can quickly become expensive. text: I'm not saying this is you <@UPMUFSGCR> - but I'm always aware that there are people reading this for whom betting is never going to work and they're just compounding losses. I think we need to be responsible to those people as well. I don't know your situation; but in general if people are telling you to cut back it's probably because they care about you and it's likely to have some foundation.

elements.text: I'm not saying this is you

- but I'm always aware that there are people reading this for whom betting is never going to work and they're just compounding losses. I think we need to be responsible to those people as well. I don't know your situation; but in general if people are telling you to cut back it's probably because they care about you and it's likely to have some foundation.
